case_name: State of Orissa v. the dealer

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 507-508 of 1963 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 507-508 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 4, 1950, of the Orissa High Court in Special Jurisdiction Cases Nos. 38 and 39 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 4, 1950, of the Orissa High Court in Special Jurisdiction Cases Nos. 38 and 39 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 4, 1950, of the Orissa High Court in Special Jurisdiction Cases Nos. 38 and 39 of 1958. Ganapathy Iyer and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant  in both the appeals . Sen and S. N. Mukherjee, for the respondents  in both the appeals . April 21, 1964.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by SIKRI, J. on April 21, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: April 21, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SIKRI, J.-The respondent, hereinafter referred to as the the dealer, filed a return for the quarter ending June 30, 1951, under the Orirsa Sales Tax Act  Orissa Act XIV of 1947   hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: The respondent (dealer) filed a return for the quarter ending June 30, 1951, under the Orissa Sales Tax Act (Orissa Act XIV of 1947).

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, hereinafter referred to as the the dealer, filed a return for the quarter ending June 30, 1951, under the Orirsa Sales Tax Act  Orissa Act XIV of 1947   hereinafter referred to as the Act . He claimed a deduction of Rs. 2,40,000/- under s. 5 2  a  ii  in respect of the goods sold to a registered dealer, named M s. Lal Co. Ltd., BA 1335.

facts.text: Dealer claimed deduction of Rs. 2,40,000/- under s. 5(2)(a)(ii) for goods sold to registered dealer Ms. Lal Co. Ltd., BA 1335, for quarter ending June 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: He claimed a deduction of Rs. 2,40,000/- under s. 5 2  a  ii  in respect of the goods sold to a registered dealer, named M s. Lal Co. Ltd., BA 1335. Similarly, for the quarter ending September 30. 1951, he claimed a deduction of Rs. 15,677/1/3.

facts.text: Dealer claimed deduction of Rs. 15,677/1/3 under s. 5(2)(a)(ii) for quarter ending September 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, for the quarter ending September 30. 1951, he claimed a deduction of Rs. 15,677/1/3. By two assessment orders passed under s. 12 2  of the Act, the Sales Tax Officer, Cuttack III circle, Jaipur, Orissa, determined the tax payable allowing the deduction of Rs. 2,40,000/- and Rs. 15,677/l/3, under s. 5 2  a  ii .

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer, Cuttack III circle, Jaipur, Orissa, passed two assessment orders under s. 12(2) allowing deductions of Rs. 2,40,000/- and Rs. 15,677/1/3.

anchor.surface_text: By two assessment orders passed under s. 12 2  of the Act, the Sales Tax Officer, Cuttack III circle, Jaipur, Orissa, determined the tax payable allowing the deduction of Rs. 2,40,000/- and Rs. 15,677/l/3, under s. 5 2  a  ii . The dealer filed appeals to the Assistant Collector, Sales Tax, challenging the assesment on grounds which are number relevant.

facts.text: Dealer filed appeals to the Assistant Collector, Sales Tax, challenging the assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The dealer filed appeals to the Assistant Collector, Sales Tax, challenging the assesment on grounds which are number relevant. The dealer later filed revisions against the decision of the Assistant Collector.

facts.text: Dealer filed revisions against the decision of the Assistant Collector while revisions were pending.

anchor.surface_text: The dealer later filed revisions against the decision of the Assistant Collector. While the revisions were pending, the legislature amended the Orissa Sales Tax Act, in 1957, by Orissa Sales Tax  Amendment  Act  Orissa Act XX of 1957 .

facts.text: Orissa Sales Tax Act amended in 1957 by Orissa Act XX of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: While the revisions were pending, the legislature amended the Orissa Sales Tax Act, in 1957, by Orissa Sales Tax  Amendment  Act  Orissa Act XX of 1957 . The effect of this amendment was that revisions were treated as appeals to Sales Tax Tribunal, and it enabled the Government to file cross-objec- tions.

facts.text: Amendment treated revisions as appeals to Sales Tax Tribunal and enabled Government to file cross-objections.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of this amendment was that revisions were treated as appeals to Sales Tax Tribunal, and it enabled the Government to file cross-objec- tions. The State of Orissa, in pursuance of this amendment, filed memorandum of cross-objections challenging the deduc- tion of Rs. 2,40,000/- and Rs. 15,677/l/3, on the ground that the dealer had number produced any declaration, as required under r. 27 2  of the Orissa Sales Tax Rules, 1947, as evidenced from the Check Sheet kept on record.

facts.text: State of Orissa filed memorandum of cross-objections challenging deductions of Rs. 2,40,000/- and Rs. 15,677/1/3 on ground that dealer had not produced declaration under r. 27(2) as per Check Sheet.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Orissa, in pursuance of this amendment, filed memorandum of cross-objections challenging the deduc- tion of Rs. 2,40,000/- and Rs. 15,677/l/3, on the ground that the dealer had number produced any declaration, as required under r. 27 2  of the Orissa Sales Tax Rules, 1947, as evidenced from the Check Sheet kept on record. The Tribunal upheld this objection and directed that fresh assessments be made.

facts.text: Tribunal upheld the objection regarding no declaration and directed fresh assessments.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal upheld this objection and directed that fresh assessments be made. Certain other questions were raised before the Tribunal by the dealer, but as numberhing turns on them as far as these appeals are companycerned, they are number being mentioned.

facts.text: Tribunal stated a case to the High Court including question whether assessing officer was wrong in allowing deductions.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal stated a case to the High Court and one of the questions referred to was whether the assessing officer was number wrong in allowing deduction of Rs. 2,40,000/- for the quarter ending on 30-6-51 and Rs. 15,677/1/3 for the quarter ending on 30-9-51 from the respective gross turnover of the applicant.

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the affirmative following earlier decision in Member, Sales-tax Tribunal, Orissa v. Messrs S. Lal Co. Limited.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, following its earlier decision in Member, Sales-tax Tribunal, Orissa v. Messrs S. Lal Co. Limited  1  answered the question in the affirmative. The State of Orissa having obtained special leave from this Court, these appeals are number before us for disposal.

facts.text: State of Orissa obtained special leave from Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Orissa having obtained special leave from this Court, these appeals are number before us for disposal. Mr. Ganapathy lyer, on behalf of the State of Orissa, has companytended before us that it is clear that r. 27 2  was number companyplied with, and, therefore, the Sales Tax Officer was wrong  1   1961  12 S.T.C. 25.

facts.text: State contended that r. 27(2) was not complied with and no declaration produced.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ganapathy lyer, on behalf of the State of Orissa, has companytended before us that it is clear that r. 27 2  was number companyplied with, and, therefore, the Sales Tax Officer was wrong  1   1961  12 S.T.C. 25. in allowing the said deduction.

facts.text: Dealer had not produced any declaration as required under r. 27(2) of Orissa Sales Tax Rules, 1947, as evidenced from Check Sheet.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that the dealer had number produced any declaration, as required under r. 27 2  of the Orissa Sales Tax Rules, 1947, as evidenced from the Check Sheet kept on record.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer was satisfied by a mere statement of the dealer.

anchor.surface_text: In this case, the Sales Tax Officer was satisfied by a mere statement of the dealer and it has number been shown that in fact the registration certificate of the buying dealer, M / s S. Lal Co., did number companytain the statement that the goods were intended for resale by him in Orissa.

facts.text: It has not been shown that the registration certificate of Ms. Lal Co. did not contain the statement that goods were intended for resale in Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: and it has number been shown that in fact the registration certificate of the buying dealer, M / s S. Lal Co., did number companytain the statement that the goods were intended for resale by him in Orissa. The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that production of declaration under r. 27(2) is not always obligatory; other evidence sufficient if STO satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the High Court came to a companyrect companyclusion. The High Court is companyrect in holding that the production of a declaration under r. 27 2  is number always obligatory on the part of a selling dealer when claiming the exemption.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Certain other questions raised before Tribunal by dealer, but not relevant to these appeals.

facts.text: Ganapathy Iyer argued for appellant (State of Orissa) in both appeals.

anchor.surface_text: Ganapathy Iyer and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant  in both the appeals . Sen and S. N. Mukherjee, for the respondents  in both the appeals . April 21, 1964.

facts.text: Sen and S. N. Mukherjee argued for respondents in both appeals.

anchor.surface_text: Sen and S. N. Mukherjee, for the respondents  in both the appeals . April 21, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SIKRI, J.-The respondent, hereinafter referred to as the the dealer,

under s. 5 2  a  ii  in respect of the goods sold to a registered dealer, named M s. Lal Co. Ltd., BA 1335. Similarly, for the quarter ending September 30. 1951, he claimed a deduction of Rs. 15,677/1/3. By two assessment orders passed under s. 12 2  of the Act, the Sales Tax Officer, Cuttack III circle, Jaipur, Orissa, determined the tax payable allowing the deduction of Rs. 2,40,000/- and Rs. 15,677/l/3, under s. 5 2  a  ii . The dealer filed appeals to the Assistant Collector, Sales Tax, challenging the assesment on grounds which are number relevant. The dealer later filed revisions against the decision of the Assistant Collector. While the revisions were pending, the legislature amended the Orissa Sales Tax Act, in 1957, by Orissa Sales Tax  Amendment  Act  Orissa Act XX of 1957 . The effect of this amendment was that revisions were treated as appeals to Sales Tax Tribunal, and it enabled the Government to file cross-objec- tions. The State of Orissa, in pursuance of this amendment, filed memorandum of cross-objections challenging the deduc- tion of Rs. 2,40,000/- and Rs. 15,677/l/3, on the ground that the dealer had number produced any declaration, as required under r. 27 2  of the Orissa Sales Tax Rules, 1947, as evidenced from the Check Sheet kept on record. The Tribunal upheld this objection and directed that fresh assessments be made. Certain other questions were raised before the Tribunal by the dealer, but as numberhing turns on them as far as these appeals are companycerned, they are number being mentioned. The Tribunal stated a case to the High Court and one of the questions referred to was whether the assessing officer was number wrong in allowing deduction of Rs. 2,40,000/- for the quarter ending on 30-6-51 and Rs. 15,677/1/3 for the quarter ending on 30-9-51 from the respective gross turnover of the applicant. The High Court, following its earlier decision in Member, Sales-tax Tribunal, Orissa v. Messrs S. Lal Co. Limited  1  answered the question in the affirmative. The State of Orissa having obtained special leave from this Court, these appeals are number before us for disposal. Mr. Ganapathy lyer, on behalf of the State of Orissa, has companytended before us that it is clear that r. 27 2  was number companyplied with, and, therefore, the Sales Tax Officer was wrong  1   1961  12 S.T.C. 25. in allowing the said deduction. The answer to the question referred depends on the companyrect interpretation of s. 5 2  a  ii , Co. and r. 27 2 . They read thus - s. 5 2  a  ii -sales to a registered dealer of goods specified in the purchasing dealers certificate of registration as being intended for resale by him in Orissa and on sales to a registered dealer of companytainers or other materials for the packing of such goods. Provided that when such goods are used by the registered dealer for purposes other than those specified in his certificate of registration, the price of goods so utilised shall be included in his taxable turnover.

concepts.interpretation: Entitles selling dealer to deduction for sales to registered dealer if goods specified in purchasing dealer's certificate for resale in Orissa; no other condition imposed; proviso includes misused goods in buyer's turnover.

anchor.surface_text: r. 27 2  of the Orissa Sales Tax Rules, 1947, as evidenced from the Check Sheet kept on record. The Tribunal upheld this objection and directed that fresh assessments be made. Certain other questions were raised before the Tribunal by the dealer, but as numberhing turns on them as far as these appeals are companycerned, they are number being mentioned. The Tribunal stated a case to the High Court and one of the questions referred to was whether the assessing officer was number wrong in allowing deduction of Rs. 2,40,000/- for the quarter ending on 30-6-51 and Rs. 15,677/1/3 for the quarter ending on 30-9-51 from the respective gross turnover of the applicant. The High Court, following its earlier decision in Member, Sales-tax Tribunal, Orissa v. Messrs S. Lal Co. Limited  1  answered the question in the affirmative. The State of Orissa having obtained special leave from this Court, these appeals are number before us for disposal. Mr. Ganapathy lyer, on behalf of the State of Orissa, has companytended before us that it is clear that r. 27 2  was number companyplied with, and, therefore, the Sales Tax Officer was wrong  1   1961  12 S.T.C. 25. in allowing the said deduction. The answer to the question referred depends on the companyrect interpretation of s. 5 2  a  ii , Co. and r. 27 2 . They read thus - s. 5 2  a  ii -sales to a registered dealer of goods specified in the purchasing dealers certificate of registration as being intended for resale by him in Orissa and on sales to a registered dealer of companytainers or other materials for the packing of such goods. Provided that when such goods are used by the registered dealer for purposes other than those specified in his certificate of registration, the price of goods so utilised shall be included in his taxable turnover. Rule 27 2 . Claims for deduction of turnover under sub-clause  ii  of clause  a  of sub- section  2  of section 5- A dealer who wishes to deduct from his gross turnover on sales which have taken place in Orissa the amount of a sale on the ground that he is entitled to make such deduction under sub-clause  ii  of clause  a  of sub-section  2  of section 5 of the Act, shall produce a companyy of the relevant cash receipt ,or bill according as the sale is a cash sale or a sale .on credit in respect of such sale and a true declaration in writing by the purchasing dealer or by such responsible person as may be authorised in writing in this behalf by such dealer that the goods in question are specified in the purchasing dealers certificate of registration as being required for resale by him or in the execution of any companytract Provided that numberdealer whose certificate of registration has number been renewed for the year during which the purchase is made shall make such a declaration and that the selling dealer shall number be entitled to claim any deduction of sales to such a dealer.

concepts.interpretation: Directory, not mandatory; production of declaration not always obligatory; must be substantially complied with; other evidence suffices if Sales Tax Officer is satisfied that certificate contains requisite statement.

They read thus - s. 5 2  a  ii -sales to a registered dealer of goods specified in the purchasing dealers certificate of registration as being intended for resale by him in Orissa

issues.text: Whether r. 27(2) is mandatory or directory

anchor.surface_text: Rule 27 2  is mandatory and if there is breach of it the selling dealer is number entitled to deduction. The learned companynsel for the res- pondent, on the other hand, companytends that r. 27 2  is directory.

issues.text: Whether production of a declaration under r. 27(2) is always obligatory on the part of a selling dealer when claiming the exemption under s. 5(2)(a)(ii)

anchor.surface_text: The High Court is companyrect in holding that the production of a declaration under r. 27 2  is number always obligatory on the part of a selling dealer when claiming the exemption. It is open to him to claim exemption by adducing other evidence

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ganapathy lyer, on behalf of the State of Orissa, has companytended before us that it is clear that r. 27 2  was number companyplied with, and, therefore, the Sales Tax Officer was wrong  1   1961  12 S.T.C. 25.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: en one exclusive method of proving the fact before a Sales Tax Officer. He further urges that numberother method of proving that fact is permissible.

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule directory; substantial compliance via other evidence possible

arguments.claim: Rule 27(2) designed as exclusive method to prove certificate specifies goods for resale; no other proof permissible; rule mandatory, breach disentitles deduction

anchor.surface_text: But Mr. Ganapathy lyer says, be it so, but the rule making authority is entitled to make ruler, for carrying out the purposes of the Act, and r. 27 2  is designed to ensure that a buying dealers certificate of registration does, in fact, mention that the goods are intended for resale by him, and for that purpose it has chosen one exclusive method of proving the fact before a Sales Tax Officer. He further urges that numberother method of proving that fact is permissible. Rule 27 2  is mandatory and if there is breach of it the selling dealer is number entitled to deduction.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: that a selling ,dealer is entitled to a deduction in respect of sales to a registered dealer of goods, if the goods are specified in the purchasing d

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule reconciled with section by treating as directory; other evidence allowed if STO satisfied

arguments.claim: r. 27(2) is directory; 'shall' read as 'may'; producing original registration certificate should suffice, otherwise absurd

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel for the res- pondent, on the other hand, companytends that r. 27 2  is directory. He points out that the word shall should be read as may, in the companytext. He further says that supposing the selling dealer brought the original certificate of registration of a buying dealer and produced it before the Sales Tax Officer, according to the appellant, this would number be enough, but this companyld never have been intended.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: that a selling ,dealer is entitled to a deduction in respect of sales to a registered dealer of goods, if the goods are specified in the purchasing d

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed directory and other evidence ok, but requires substantial compliance

arguments.claim: Under s.5(2)(a)(ii), selling dealer entitled to deduction if goods specified in purchasing dealer's certificate for resale in Orissa; no other condition imposed by section; proviso only affects buying dealer on misuse

anchor.surface_text: It is, plain from the terms of s. 5 2  a  ii  that a selling ,dealer is entitled to a deduction in respect of sales to a registered dealer of goods, if the goods are specified in the purchasing dealers certificate of registration as being intended for re-sale by him in Orissa. No other companydition is imposed by the above section. The proviso deals with companysequences that follow if the purchasing dealer uses them for purposes other than those specified in his certificate of registration, and ,directs that, in that event, the price of goods so utilised shall be included in his turnover.

arguments.claim: r.27(2) must be read harmoniously with s.5(2)(a)(ii) by treating rule as directory, not mandatory; substantial compliance required; STO can be satisfied by other evidence or facts

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, r. 27 2  must be reconciled with the section and the rule can be reconciled by treating it as directory. But the rule must be substantially companyplied with in every case. It is for the Sales Tax Officer to be satisfied that, in fact, the certificate of registration of the buying dealer companytains the requisite Statement, and if he has any doubts about it, the selling dealer must satisfy his doubts. But if he is satisfied from other facts on the record, it is number necessary that the selling dealer should produce a declaration in the form required in r. 27 2 , before being entitled to a deduction.

arguments.claim: Production of declaration under r.27(2) not always obligatory for exemption under s.5(2)(a)(ii); other evidence suffices to satisfy STO

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the High Court came to a companyrect companyclusion. The High Court is companyrect in holding that the production of a declaration under r. 27 2  is number always obligatory on the part of a selling dealer when claiming the exemption.

arguments.claim: Assessing officer not wrong in allowing deductions, following precedent in Member, Sales-tax Tribunal v. S. Lal Co.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, following its earlier decision in Member, Sales-tax Tribunal, Orissa v. Messrs S. Lal Co. Limited  1  answered the question in the affirmative.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tion and the rule can be reconciled by treating it as directory. But the rule must be substantially companyplied with in every case. It is for the Sal

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court correct; SC agrees with its conclusion

arguments.claim: In this case, STO satisfied by mere statement of dealer; not shown that buying dealer's certificate did not contain statement for resale in Orissa

anchor.surface_text: In this case, the Sales Tax Officer was satisfied by a mere statement of the dealer and it has number been shown that in fact the registration certificate of the buying dealer, M / s S. Lal Co., did number companytain the statement that the goods were intended for resale by him in Orissa.

holdings.text: A selling dealer is entitled to a deduction under s. 5(2)(a)(ii) in respect of sales to a registered dealer of goods specified in the purchasing dealer's certificate of registration as being intended for resale by him in Orissa; no other condition is imposed by the section.

anchor.surface_text: It is, plain from the terms of s. 5 2  a  ii  that a selling ,dealer is entitled to a deduction in respect of sales to a registered dealer of goods, if the goods are specified in the purchasing dealers certificate of registration as being intended for re-sale by him in Orissa. No other companydition is imposed by the above section. The proviso deals with companysequences that follow if the purchasing dealer uses them for purposes other than those specified in his certificate of registration, and ,directs that, in that event, the price of goods so utilised shall be included in his turnover.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual reading of s. 5(2)(a)(ii); proviso applies only to buyer on misuse, no disentitlement for seller.

holdings.text: r. 27(2) must be reconciled with s. 5(2)(a)(ii) by treating the rule as directory rather than mandatory, but it must be substantially complied with; the Sales Tax Officer may be satisfied by other evidence or facts on record without the specific declaration.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, r. 27 2  must be reconciled with the section and the rule can be reconciled by treating it as directory. But the rule must be substantially companyplied with in every case. It is for the Sales Tax Officer to be satisfied that, in fact, the certificate of registration of the buying dealer companytains the requisite Statement, and if he has any doubts about it, the selling dealer must satisfy his doubts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of rule and section; 'shall' read contextually as directory to avoid absurdity; substantial compliance suffices for purpose of verifying certificate contents.

holdings.text: The production of a declaration under r. 27(2) is not always obligatory on the part of a selling dealer when claiming the exemption under s. 5(2)(a)(ii); it is open to claim exemption by adducing other evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the High Court came to a companyrect companyclusion. The High Court is companyrect in holding that the production of a declaration under r. 27 2  is number always obligatory on the part of a selling dealer when claiming the exemption. It is open to him to claim exemption by adducing other evidence so as to bring the transaction within the scope of s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirming High Court; rule directory allows alternative evidence to satisfy STO that goods are in buyer's certificate for resale.

holdings.text: The assessing officer was not wrong in allowing the deductions as he was satisfied by the dealer's statement and it has not been shown that the buying dealer's registration certificate did not contain the requisite statement for resale.

anchor.surface_text: In this case, the Sales Tax Officer was satisfied by a mere statement of the dealer and it has number been shown that in fact the registration certificate of the buying dealer, M / s S. Lal Co., did number companytain the statement that the goods were intended for resale by him in Orissa.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of directory rule to facts; absence of proof contradicting STO satisfaction; substantial compliance achieved.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals by the State of Orissa dismissed; High Court correct in holding that declaration under r. 27(2) not always obligatory for deduction under s. 5(2)(a)(ii)

edges.explanation: Supreme Court precedent that production not always obligatory grounds similar holding for substantial compliance

anchor.surface_text: It is, plain from the terms of s. 5 2  a  ii  that a selling ,dealer is entitled to a deduction in respect of sales to a registered dealer of goods, if the goods are specified in the purchasing dealers certificate of registration as being intended for re-sale by him in Orissa. No other companydition is imposed by the above section. The proviso deals with companysequences that follow if the purchasing dealer uses them for purposes other than those specified in his certificate of registration, and ,directs that, in that event, the price of goods so utilised shall be included in his turnover.
The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding applying directory reading supports the doctrine by showing it enables reconciliation without rewriting

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, r. 27 2  must be reconciled with the section and the rule can be reconciled by treating it as directory. But the rule must be substantially companyplied with in every case. It is for the Sales Tax Officer to be satisfied that, in fact, the certificate of registration of the buying dealer companytains the requisite Statement, and if he has any doubts about it, the selling dealer must satisfy his doubts.
The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding that alternatives open embodies and supports substantial compliance
Holding directly answers the issue by stating production not always obligatory

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the High Court came to a companyrect companyclusion. The High Court is companyrect in holding that the production of a declaration under r. 27 2  is number always obligatory on the part of a selling dealer when claiming the exemption. It is open to him to claim exemption by adducing other evidence so as to bring the transaction within the scope of s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Act.
The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts.

In this case, the Sales Tax Officer was satisfied by a mere statement of the dealer and it has number been shown that in fact the registration certificate of the buying dealer, M / s S. Lal Co., did number companytain the statement that the goods were intended for resale by him in Orissa.
The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts.
